review_title: Decent pay/benefits, understaffed, high turnover/burnout, maybe look at other health systems first
pros:
- Pay is slightly better than competing health systems in Western Mass for pharmacists
- Staff are mostly reliable, cooperative, and want to take good care of patients
- Membership in several state pharmacy organizations including MSHP and HPWM
- Free online continuing education credits earned through Pharmacists Letter, live CE given by pharmacy residents, medical grand rounds, and pharmacy specialists almost weekly
- Partial reimbursement for board certification
- Lots of opportunities to precept pharmacy students if you are interested
- Lots of technology used in delivery of pharmacy services; experience looks great on a resume/CV
- Diverse patient population if you're allowed to work in different care areas
- Lower management and supervisors are motivated to make improvements to department, but progress is limited by weak advocacy and disordered priorities of directors and execs above pharmacy
- You can advance very quickly if you can convince senior management you're a pushover (even if you're not the type, fake it until you make it; senior management dislikes assertive employees)
- As bad as it can be here, it is better than retail by a big margin
cons:
- Very high turnover, especially for technicians
- Pay is not competitive for technicians
- Directors struggle to accept constructive criticism
- The department doesn't hire enough staff to meet minimum staffing requirements, regularly pesters staff with overtime demands to fill holes, burn out is high
- Directors are weak advocates for pharmacy and seem to have an inadequate understanding of staff responsibilities and daily pharmacy operations
- Favoritism is rampant; infrequent internal promotions are routinely given to people who have less experience or tenure and some poorly performing employees are given exemptions that other staff never get
- Strong workers are usually just given more work
- When employees give advance notice of leaving critical positions, department is very slow to train other employees to replace; often times, the position isn't filled and training doesn't start until the previous employee has already left, leaving big gaps in continuity and lost expertise 
- Management pays lip service to career development but in reality it is almost non-existent. Most staff who express an interest in doing more in the department are told there's no money for training unless specially-trained employees quit and they have to scramble to replace lost skill sets

job_title: Access Service Representative in Holyoke, MA
pros: Co-workers are nice, pay is good
cons: It kind of feels like a sweat shop. You only get two 10 minute breaks and a 40 minute lunch throughout the day. If you have to go to the bathroom and it is not your break time, your boss will give you a hard time. You are really not 'allowed' to leave your desk for anything. Management does play favorites, so people who have been here for 30 years get away with slacking and not taking many calls which can be frustrating. If you get caught even looking at your phone its a problem. You are basically treated like a child. At my age, I need to be treated like an adult. Their turnover rate is high due to many of these reasons. The managers walk around on their phones constantly too, Facebooking and texting and chatting away with each other but like I said if they see you even look at your phone you could get written up. Honestly it is ridiculous, as long as you get your work done you shouldn't be treated like such a child. I have never personally been written up though or really caught but I have heard stories and seen it. Baystate is not all it's cracked out to be, the pay is good and the work is easy but if you want to grow and you want to be valued and treated like an adult I wouldn't say this is the place to get that.

review_title: Who wants to be a Registered Nurse today?
pros: Some great people to work with at Baystate.  Pay is okay, pension isn't bad.
cons: After many years at Baystate, the past 5 years or so have been terrible.  Far too many employee's are now treated with a lack of respect and professionalism by many in management.  The hospitals mantra has been geared toward saving so much money in costs it now jeopardizes patient care and safety due to a lack of proper staffing.  If the subject is brought up to management, especially with nursing supervisors, you are then harrassed from that point on in an obvious attempt to get you so frustrated you will quit.  Some nursing supervisors too often cater to their 'friends' which creates a lot of discord within untis/floors.  Sadly, this seems to be the MO of a number of hospitals in MA, CT & RI, people are aware of it, consquently fewer and fewer young people/students now consider a career in nursing.  Many that do, leave the profession within five years or so, some change their majors in college once they get a taste of nursing care versus the bean counters.

pros: Large employer, many wonderful employees and managers. Career Opportunities if you are willing to work hard, be a team player and have a good attitude. Great place if you are interested in working in a busy healthcare environment. Baystate Medical Center is a Magnet Designated hospital, which is attractive to people in patient care jobs.
cons: As with all Healthcare facilities, there are lots of change going on, which isn't always a bad thing except that some long term staff can be resistant to change.

pros:
My manager is good but she is handcuffed by upper management mandate to cut every penny at every opportunity regardless of broad patient safety concerns.  
BMC used to be a more compassionate employee-sensitive place to work but is has become essentially a corporation looking to squeeze out profit with little concern for patient safety fallout.
cons:
Employee perks have slowly disappeared and along with that, morale. Visitors used to be able to fill out slip, recognizing our good work...get five and receive $50. That was cut. Now, visitor gets a "chance" to give BMC money in recognition of our good work. 

Although BMC actually own its own very profitable insurance company, all co-pays have skyrocketed and premiums continue to rise. No matter how much money they make, it's never enough. We know when we get the letter that opens, "We value your commitment..." it's time to get ready for yet more sacrifice.

Because ti is run like a business, although it is non-profit, it persists in micromanaging how nurses work. Nursing, is, in inherently unpredictable. Treating it as assembly line work results in fragmented and short staffing and unsafe patient scenarios. This has become the norm at BMC.

We lost the ability to park on campus and must now bus in from a distant lot. We must now show up 15 early(on out time)  as we often must wait until the bus is full before it departs. We are not compensated for this time. At shift's end, it is common, once again,  to have to wait for the bus to arrive.  

Recently, any work over 12 hours is straight time unless it happens to exceed 40-hours.
One might think having to stay beyond 12 hours in order to complete the workload might constitute a dedication worthy of overtime. Not anymore.

Finally, as  part-timer, my insurance premium is about 300% more than a full timer, same coverage, same policy. I asked the CEO to rationalize this gross disparity....to paraphrase, he told me others do it so we do it.
